front.p: Undated enclosure, Octavius to Octavia Hadfield

body.p: It gave me great pleasure to see a few lines from you in my mother’s letter, as tho’ I have never forgotten you it recalled you more particularly to my recollection. I am sorry you should have thought the stormy weather [page repeated – I think during corrections] should have hurt me but I am always lucky you must remember in future, for when I came out no sailor on board had ever experienced such a delightful passage and every vessel that has arrived has had bad weather. I should like to have you out here sometimes when I see anything that is very pretty. I amuse myself sometimes looking for flowers, but tho’ everything will grow here there are very few wild flowers. If I can find any that I think you have not got I will try and bring them. I have only a few minutes to write in as the Ellen is going to sail directly but I could not let an opportunity escape me as you are all so very kind as to feel pleasure in hearing from me. I look forward to the time when we may meet again. Tell my mother in answer to her question that Mrs. Iven’s name is Mary Ann. They all [wish] to be remembered. And now my dear Octavia you must give my love and a big kiss to them all round for me, and
